body.p: T E Bramlett Gov. of Kentucky

Your petitioner Edward B Mitchall would state that some time in the month of October 1862 James D. Amos I had learned there was engaged with the gurrillas in feering into the S B Nashville on the Ohio River at whats called Bucks Island abot six miles above Caseyville Union County Ky I charged said Amos with being concerned in the shooting in the boat he cursed me called me a Dam lyar and a dam Linconite I returned the lye in the same language Amos is a large man weighs ovo 200 pounds and overbaring I weigh about 145 pounds Amos drew a pistol on me and shot the ball gowing through my clothes we then clenchid I succeedid in getting his pistol ater he had me down he got off of me as soon as I got the pistol and run I shot at him twice ^one^ of the shots struck him in the back on tretched his hand it was Amos own pistol I shot him with and the same he fired at the passanir of the stemer Nashville with I am and always have been a Union man and that was the whole cause of our difficulty said Amos often said he would drive every Union man from his neighorhood

The Grand Jury found bills agains myself and Amos and the October term of the Union Circuit Court I was fined seventy five dollars. All the witnesses were what is call Sothern Simpethisers or Rebills In the part of the county that I reside in there was only three Union men besides myself. And under the circumstances, your petitioner would humbly ask your Excilancy to remit the fine of 75$. Amos was fined the same amount
Sworn to and subscribed before me this 24 day of October 1863

Attest
J W Fennie P. J. C.

We the undersigned Union Men of Union County would respectfully ask the Governor of Kentucky T E Bramlet to remit the fine of seventy five dollars imposed on E B Mitchall at the October term of said Court we know Mitchall to be a true and loyal man and dont think he should be made pay one cent for shooting Dr. James D Amos. We know Amos and when he had his Rebells with him he is overbaring and very abrusive Further we think Mitchell under the circumstances would have been justifiable had he killed Amos at the time
We would respectfully ask your exclency to interpose your authority and remit said fine your Respectfully

J W Fennie
